thread.title: Johnny Cueto’s lame excuses for pitiful Game 3 performance
thread.title_full: Johnny Cueto’s lame excuses for pitiful Game 3 performance | New York Post

author: George A. King III
title: Johnny Cueto’s lame excuses for pitiful Game 3 performance
text:
TORONTO — Add a whining Johnny Cueto to the long list of pitchers who get shelled at Rogers Centre and blamed it on the Blue Jays stealing signs.
In Monday night’s Game 3 between the Royals and Blue Jays, Cueto was rocked for eight runs and six hits in two-plus innings and never gave his club a chance in what turned out to be an 11-8 Toronto victory.
And that wasn’t Cueto’s lone complaint. He blamed the beating on the mound not being to his liking.
Cueto told fellow pitcher Edinson Volquez, who starts Game 5 for the Royals on Wednesday — on the same mound Cueto was knocked from — he thought the Blue Jays somehow were swiping signs.
Cueto isn’t the first person to believe the Blue Jays knew what was coming. When current Toronto catcher Russell Martin was with the Yankees, he accused the Blue Jays of stealing signs at home.
“I think he said, [Monday night] they had a guy in center field,’’ Volquez said of Cueto, who threw a wad of bubble gum on the artificial turf as he was exiting the game. “He looks to center field and he sees somebody do this or that, it’s really hard to do that. I don’t know, but he said that.
“When a guy gets on second base he said something about that, too, that they were giving signs to the hitter, but I don’t know.’’
Talk of the Blue Jays stealing signs has been going on for years because even when they were horrid, they hit well at home — whether it was called SkyDome or Rogers Centre.
Visiting players have accused the Blue Jays of having somebody hidden in the center-field fence or in the seats tipping off hitters with hand signals. Others, including Martin, have accused Blue Jays runners on second base using hand and foot movements to alert batters of pitch location.
“That’s what I hear. We have a lot of friends on different teams, they always say that they give signs,’’ Volquez said. “But I don’t go crazy with it. You can tell if you are good or not when you are pitching, the way they take pitches and maybe the guy moving to second base or whatever it is but I don’t keep that in my mind.’’
